[Ri]ght wurshipfull I very well
ceyve of the l
re
s of o
r
brethern at
Middleburgh
yo
r
care
[.]se toward
us touchinge that weightie cause of Taringe Englishe cloathes in the
[united]
vync
/ For w
ch
we yeild unto youe o
r
most hartie thank
acknoledginge oure self
[.] beholden to youe therein As that the thankfull memorie therof must remayne wth us, [out .]
[.] imprynte uppon o
r
selff
the note of fowle Ingratitude / yo
r
former kyndnes receved [.]
[.]itly embolden us to laye open unto youe thestate of o
r
cause accordinge to that we ca
n
[.]e understande therof. First yf this matter of Tare shuld be brought unto the censur[e of the]
[Tar]e m
rs
in ev
r
y towne whereunto o
r
clothe is carryed in these
vync
after the same is bough[t to]
[Mi]ddleburgh as by the placarde allredy sett oute is decreed. Thereby these Tare m
rs
shall have [.]
[.]an hande ov
r
us as that
thereby
at their pleasure They maye eyther undoo us or compell [us to]
leave or trade in those cuntreys / For when as the buyar him sellf after he hathe the clothe[s]
[.] owne
house
maye there p
r
vatelie open serche handle weete tenter & drye agayne the clothe [.]
[.] he bringe it to the Tare m
rs
howe maye he alter the clothe from that w
ch
it was when [it]
[w]as sold and delyv
r
d? So if all equyte and justice be in the Tare m
rs
yet suche wronge maye [.]
[.]ne to the clothes before it co
m
e to their viewe & serche / as maye not only p
r
judice their justice [.]
[.]lf intollerably domage the m
r
chant sellar against all reason & equytie / Also many of these
[Tare] m
rs
maye be secret
tners w
th
the cloathe buyers. And then if no other meane wronge be done [.]
[. c]lothe before yt co
m
e to taringe / will there be likelyhode that the tare shalbe equall /? Also [.]
[P]lacarde is restreictife & prohibytive to all free buyinge and sellinge In that it dothe restreic[t and]
[pro]hibyte all thinhabytant
of those
vinc
to buye any englishe clothe / onles yt be w
th
condition [that]
it maye be thus tared W
ch
is playnelie opposite to A free marte & against all thauncyent [.]
[. mens] and usag
of those cuntreys and directly against thenterco
r
se / And if her
Ma
itie
in
England
[.] make like edict for all m
r
chandizes of those
vinc
brought hither following their placard [.]
[.] for woorde
mutatis mutandis
/ in respect of the dyv
r
sitie of the m
r
chandizes / It were but
[.]
talionis
/ yet we think the men of those
vinc
wold think & fynde it heavie & to heavie to be [.]
[.]e / of these matters we have enlarged further to o
r
brethern all w
ch
we knowe shalbe
[.]rted to yo
r
woorship
Therfore (After o
r
Right hartie comendac
o
ns) we surcease to trouble
[you] further at this present. Only wisshinge unto yow all healthe and happynes in the lorde
[.] At London this 4
th
of Julie a
o
1592.
Yo
r
w
r
ships assured lovinge Frend
The gov
r
nor deputie & associat
of m
r
chant
adventurers resident in London. George Setherton deputye.
